answers.answer: Hello!You need to do some investigations and come to a diagnosis for the numbness. Blood sugar, blood pressure etc.1) The most common reason would be a faulty way of injecting, if you have taken any steroid in the site of the pain.2) Diabetes mellitus, for this you have to go for a fasting blood sugar.3) Nerve related for this a neurologist opinion will be worthwhile.Take care!

question: Several weeks ago I went to the Dr, for pain in my right big toe, He gave me steriods and an anti inflamatory and told me to call him in 3 weeks if the pain did not get better. A week or so later my second toe the one next to my big one went numb on the side closest to the big toe. Then a few days later my baby toe on my left foot went completely numb. What would cause that? My Dr, is sending me to a specialist but did not give me a clue as what it could be. (I called him I did not go back in to see him) Should I be worried?
title: pain and numbing in the toes
